chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
text: A thin smooth rod of length L and mass M is rotating freely with angular speed ω₀ about an axis perpendicular to the rod and passing through its centre. Two beads of mass m and negligible size are at the centre of the rod initially. The beads are free to slide along the rod. The angular speed of the system, when the beads reach the opposite ends of the rod, will be
concepts_required: Moment of inertia of point masses

ncert_mapping.chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

steps.explanation: Initially beads are at center, so their contribution is zero

steps.description: Calculate final moment of inertia when beads reach ends
steps.explanation: Each bead is at distance L/2 from axis
No external torque, so angular momentum is conserved

common_mistakes.mistake: Using rod length L instead of L/2 for bead distance
common_mistakes.correct_approach: Beads are at opposite ends, each at distance L/2 from center
No external torque, so L is conserved
Beads at center contribute zero to I_i

alternative_approaches.explanation: Can verify bead contribution using I = I_cm + md²
alternative_approaches.formula: For point mass at center, I_cm = 0, so I = m(L/2)²

key_insights: Angular momentum is conserved when no external torque acts
As moment of inertia increases, angular velocity must decrease
The factor of 6 comes from two beads each at (L/2)²
Internal forces (normal reactions) don't affect angular momentum conservation
prerequisite_knowledge: Understanding of external vs internal torques
